definition:
Let $L$ be a first order language. A formula $\psi$ is [*quantifier
free*]{} iff it contains no quantifiers.

Let $T$ be a complete $L$-theory. Let $S \subseteq L$. Then $S$ is an
[*elimination set*]{} for $T$ iff for every $\psi(\bar{x}) \in L$ there
is some $\phi(\bar{x}) \in S$ so that
$T \vdash \forall \bar{x} (\psi(\bar{x})) \leftrightarrow \phi(\bar{x})$.

In particular, $T$ has [*quantifier elimination*]{} iff the set of
quantifier free formulas is an elimination set for $T$. In other $T$ has
[*quantifier elimination*]{} iff for every $\psi(\bar{x}) \in L$ there
is some quantifier free $\phi(\bar{x}) \in L$ so that
$T \vdash \forall \bar{x} (\psi(\bar{x})) \leftrightarrow \phi(\bar{x})$.
